author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Sentences Activist to Penal Colony for Antiwar Notes on Price Tags
description: A court sentenced Aleksandra Y. Skochilenko to seven years in a penal colony, in one of the most prominent cases of Russia’s crackdown on wartime dissent.
content: A Russian court has sentenced a pacifist artist to seven years in a penal colony for leaving price tags with small antiwar messages in a supermarket, the latest example of the Kremlin’s resolve to stamp out opposition to Russia’s war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: George Tscherny, Whose Graphic Designs Defined an Era, Is Dead at 99
description: With a bevy of corporate and institutional clients, he helped shape the visual language of the postwar American economy.
content: George Tscherny, a leading figure in postwar graphic design whose work unified the crisp, clean lines of European modern art with an American commercial pop sensibility, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Nothing Could Stop Their Relationship From Heating Up
description: Jamie Kalman needed a fire performer for an event she was producing and was about to hire Aubrey DePew, but then the pandemic happened.
content: Jamie Leigh Kalman was looking for someone who could eat and breathe fire for an upcoming event she was producing in Pensacola, Fla. So she reached out to Aubrey Nicole DePew, who had precisely those skills, on Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Isabella Kwai
title: Amtrak Train Derails in Michigan After Striking Vehicle on Tracks
description: The accident occurred near Lake Michigan an hour east of Chicago. The engineer and about 10 passengers were treated for injuries, the local authorities said.
content: An Amtrak passenger train carrying more than 200 passengers derailed in Michigan on Thursday night after striking a vehicle on the tracks, injuring 11 people, the local authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Alex Murdaugh Pleads Guilty to Spate of Financial Crimes
description: In accepting the new plea deal, Mr. Murdaugh admitted to stealing from clients for years while he was working as an influential lawyer in rural South Carolina.
content: Alex Murdaugh, the former lawyer who was convicted this year of murdering his wife and son, pleaded guilty on Friday to a spate of money laundering and other financial crimes, fortifying the prospect that he will spend decades in prison even as he seeks a retrial in his murder case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Eli Roth Takes a Stab at Thanksgiving Horror
description: Ever since he was a boy, the director has wanted to make a gory movie about the holiday. “Thanksgiving” is adapted from his 2007 faux trailer.
content: For almost every holiday, there’s a horror movie, from “My Bloody Valentine” to “Black Christmas.” Thanksgiving, too. But the turkeys-beware holiday gets its own namesake movie with Eli Roth’s “Thanksgiving,” featuring an ensemble cast that includes Addison Rae, Patrick Dempsey and Gina Gershon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: After ‘Saltburn,’ Watch These Five Country House Movies
description: From upstairs to downstairs and the challenging moments in between, a walk through a particular subgenre of films ripe for dramatic tension.
content: If “Promising Young Woman” was Emerald Fennell’s darkly comic take on the rape-revenge thriller — one that rode a zeitgeisty wave of discourse onto a best original screenplay Oscar in 2021 — “Saltburn” is the writer-director’s entry in the country house canon. The film (in theaters) is the latest in a subgenre ripe for dramatic tension: upstairs versus downstairs; invited versus interloped; public versus private. Away from prying eyes, characters in these tales tend to revel in their idyllic surroundings as unseen, often sinister, forces work against them, resulting in an unforgettable stay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Judge Denies Trump’s Request for a Mistrial in Fraud Case
description: The judge, Arthur F. Engoron, used the denial as an opportunity to defend his handling of the case. The former president’s allies have accused him of political bias.
content: The New York state judge presiding over Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud trial defended his work on Friday as he rejected a mistrial bid from the former president’s lawyers in which they had accused him of political bias.
source.name: The New York Times

title: China Wants to Bulldoze Old Neighborhoods to Revive the Economy
description: The halting revitalization of one “urban village” in Shenzhen shows the challenges of fixing a national property crisis after years of overborrowing.
content: In Shenzhen, a metropolis born of China’s economic prosperity, Paibang Village is a reminder of the city’s modest past and the challenges ahead for reviving the country’s property sector.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giri Nathan
title: Michael Lewis Tells His Own Story of Sam Bankman-Fried
description: “Going Infinite” may have missed the big takeaway, but it offers at least one undeniable pleasure: deep access.
content: If Michael Lewis’s chief talent is explaining how a misunderstood outsider’s penetrating insights allow him to win at a complex game, then Sam Bankman-Fried stretches that literary muscle in a different, less comfortable direction. Bankman-Fried — who was briefly the world’s richest person under 30, until the abrupt collapse of his cryptocurrency exchange FTX in late 2022 — is an outsider, in some sense, but it’s not clear that he had a penetrating insight, or that he won a game in any way that we should respect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Red-Crowned Parrots Are Beloved in L.A. County. Who’s Trapping Them?
description: The bird, a nonnative species whose population ballooned in the 1970s and 80s, became emblematic of Temple City, Calif.
content: For decades, the residents of Temple City, Calif., had learned to love their shrill avian neighbors — expecting to be woken by a cacophony of squawks, and anticipating their return at dusk to roost in the trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Goodbye, Feminist Blogs. Hello, Gen Z Content Creators?
description: Young women are more feminist than ever, as are big brands and Hollywood franchises. But what happened to the online community blogs and zines once offered?
content: Rayne Fisher-Quann grew up with no shortage of feminist influences. There was her mother, who brought home a book about the problems with Barbie and banned the actual dolls. There were websites transmitting the wise and world-weary voices of fired-up millennial thinkers — the women’s blog Jezebel, the teen site Rookie. Now that Ms. Fisher-Quann is establishing herself as an independent writer focused on girlhood and identity, she wonders how her career might unfold if there were a more cohesive online community for Gen Z feminists like herself.
source.name: The New York Times
